canonical_explanation.text: Ray optics treats light as straight-line rays and explains reflection, refraction, and image formation by mirrors and lenses. The law of reflection states that the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection (∠i = ∠r), and the incident ray, reflected ray, and normal lie in the same plane. The mirror formula is 1/v + 1/u = 1/f, and magnification m = −v/u. Snell's law of refraction: n₁ sin i = n₂ sin r, where n is the refractive index of the medium. Total internal reflection (TIR) occurs when light travels from a denser to a rarer medium and the angle of incidence exceeds the critical angle θ_c, where sin θ_c = n₂/n₁ (n₁ > n₂). TIR is the basis for optical fibres and the sparkling of diamonds. A prism deviates light; the angle of deviation δ depends on the angle of incidence and the prism angle A. At minimum deviation δ_m, the refractive index is n = sin((A + δ_m)/2)/sin(A/2). Dispersion is the splitting of white light into its component colours by a prism because the refractive index varies with wavelength (n_violet > n_red). The lens maker's equation is 1/f = (n − 1)(1/R₁ − 1/R₂). The thin lens formula is 1/v − 1/u = 1/f, and magnification m = v/u. The power of a lens is P = 1/f (in dioptres, when f is in metres). For lenses in contact, P = P₁ + P₂. A simple microscope has magnification M = 1 + D/f (for image at near point). A compound microscope has M = m_o × m_e, where m_o = −L/f_o and m_e = 1 + D/f_e. An astronomical telescope in normal adjustment has magnification M = −f_o/f_e.
rules: Law of reflection: angle of incidence = angle of reflection
Snell's law: n₁ sin i = n₂ sin r
Total internal reflection occurs when i > θ_c; sin θ_c = n₂/n₁ (n₁ > n₂)
Prism: n = sin((A + δ_m)/2)/sin(A/2) at minimum deviation
Dispersion: n varies with wavelength; violet is deviated most
Thin lens formula: 1/v − 1/u = 1/f; magnification m = v/u
Power of lens: P = 1/f (dioptres); for combination P = P₁ + P₂
Simple microscope: M = 1 + D/f; compound microscope: M = (L/f_o)(1 + D/f_e)

questions.question_text: The mirror formula is:
questions.explanation_correct: The mirror formula is 1/v + 1/u = 1/f, where v is the image distance, u is the object distance, and f is the focal length. All distances are measured from the pole of the mirror using the sign convention (negative for real objects/images in front of concave mirror).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1/v − 1/u = 1/f is the lens formula, not the mirror formula. The mirror formula uses addition: 1/v + 1/u = 1/f. Note: with proper sign convention, all three (u, v, f) can be negative.

questions.question_text: Snell's law of refraction states:

options.text: n₁ sin i = n₂ sin r
n₁ cos i = n₂ cos r

questions.explanation_correct: Snell's law states n₁ sin i = n₂ sin r, where n₁ and n₂ are the refractive indices of the two media, i is the angle of incidence, and r is the angle of refraction. Both angles are measured from the normal to the interface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Snell's law involves sines of the angles (not cosines) and the product n × sin (not the ratio n/sin). The correct form is n₁ sin i = n₂ sin r.

questions.question_text: The magnification produced by a spherical mirror is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: The magnification of a spherical mirror is m = −v/u, where v is the image distance and u is the object distance. A negative magnification indicates an inverted image (real), while a positive magnification indicates an erect image (virtual).
questions.explanation_incorrect: For mirrors, m = −v/u (note the negative sign). For lenses, m = v/u (no negative sign in the standard convention). The negative sign in the mirror formula accounts for the inversion of real images.

questions.question_text: When light travels from a denser medium to a rarer medium, the refracted ray bends:
questions.explanation_correct: When light passes from a denser medium (higher n) to a rarer medium (lower n), the refracted ray bends away from the normal. By Snell's law, since n₁ > n₂, sin r > sin i, meaning r > i. The ray moves away from the normal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Light bends towards the normal when going from rarer to denser medium (speed decreases). When going from denser to rarer (speed increases), it bends away from the normal. This follows from Snell's law: n₁ sin i = n₂ sin r.

questions.question_text: An object is placed 30 cm in front of a concave mirror of focal length 20 cm. The image is formed at:

options.text: 60 cm in front of the mirror, real and inverted
60 cm behind the mirror, virtual and erect
12 cm in front of the mirror, real and inverted
20 cm in front of the mirror, virtual and erect

questions.explanation_correct: Using sign convention: u = −30 cm, f = −20 cm. Mirror formula: 1/v + 1/u = 1/f → 1/v = 1/f − 1/u = 1/(−20) − 1/(−30) = −1/20 + 1/30 = (−3 + 2)/60 = −1/60. So v = −60 cm. The negative sign means the image is in front of the mirror (real). m = −v/u = −(−60)/(−30) = −2 (inverted, magnified).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Applying 1/v = 1/f − 1/u with proper signs: 1/v = −1/20 + 1/30 = −1/60, giving v = −60 cm (real, in front of mirror). The image is inverted and magnified (m = −2).

questions.question_text: A ray of light passes from air (n = 1) into glass (n = 1.5) at an angle of incidence of 30°. The angle of refraction is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: Using Snell's law: n₁ sin i = n₂ sin r → 1 × sin 30° = 1.5 × sin r → sin r = 0.5/1.5 = 1/3 ≈ 0.333. Therefore r = sin⁻¹(0.333) ≈ 19.5°. The ray bends towards the normal as it enters the denser medium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: sin r = sin 30°/1.5 = 0.5/1.5 = 0.333, giving r ≈ 19.5°. Options like 45° or 48.6° would require different refractive indices or angles of incidence.

questions.question_text: The refractive index of water is 4/3. A fish at a depth of 12 cm in water appears to be at a depth of:
questions.explanation_correct: The apparent depth = real depth / n = 12/(4/3) = 12 × 3/4 = 9 cm. Objects under water appear shallower than they actually are because light bends away from the normal as it exits water into air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Apparent depth = real depth / refractive index = 12 / (4/3) = 9 cm. The object appears closer to the surface. Multiplying by n (giving 16 cm) would be incorrect — that would apply if viewing from inside water into air.

questions.question_text: A concave mirror produces a real image 3 times the size of the object. If the focal length is 12 cm, the object distance is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a real image, m = −3 (inverted). m = −v/u, so −3 = −v/u → v = 3u. Using sign convention: u is negative, f = −12 cm, v = 3u. Mirror formula: 1/v + 1/u = 1/f → 1/(3u) + 1/u = 1/(−12) → (1 + 3)/(3u) = −1/12 → 4/(3u) = −1/12 → u = −16 cm. Object is 16 cm from the mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For a real, magnified image (m = −3): v = 3u. Substituting into 1/v + 1/u = 1/f with f = −12: 4/(3u) = −1/12, giving u = −16 cm. The object is placed between F and C.

questions.question_text: A convex lens of focal length 20 cm forms a real image at 60 cm from the lens. The object distance is:
questions.explanation_correct: Using lens formula: 1/v − 1/u = 1/f. Here f = +20 cm, v = +60 cm (real image). 1/u = 1/v − 1/f = 1/60 − 1/20 = (1 − 3)/60 = −2/60 = −1/30. So u = −30 cm. The negative sign confirms the object is on the same side as the incoming light.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lens formula: 1/v − 1/u = 1/f → 1/u = 1/60 − 1/20 = −1/30, giving u = −30 cm. The object is 30 cm from the lens on the same side as the incoming light (as expected for a real object).

questions.question_text: The relationship between the focal length f and the radius of curvature R of a spherical mirror is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a spherical mirror (concave or convex), the focal length is half the radius of curvature: f = R/2. This is valid for paraxial rays (rays close to the principal axis). The focus is the midpoint between the pole and the centre of curvature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The focal length is exactly half the radius of curvature for spherical mirrors: f = R/2. This relationship is derived from the geometry of reflection for paraxial rays. f = R or f = 2R are incorrect.

questions.question_text: Total internal reflection occurs when light travels from:

options.text: a rarer medium to a denser medium
a denser medium to a rarer medium at an angle greater than the critical angle
a denser medium to a rarer medium at any angle

questions.explanation_correct: Total internal reflection (TIR) occurs when two conditions are met: (1) light must travel from a denser to a rarer medium (n₁ > n₂), and (2) the angle of incidence must exceed the critical angle θ_c. Below θ_c, both refraction and reflection occur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: TIR requires both conditions: denser-to-rarer medium AND angle of incidence > critical angle. Just going denser to rarer doesn't guarantee TIR — the angle must exceed θ_c. Light going rarer to denser never undergoes TIR.

questions.question_text: The critical angle for a medium of refractive index √2 with respect to air is:
questions.explanation_correct: sin θ_c = n_rarer/n_denser = 1/√2. Therefore θ_c = sin⁻¹(1/√2) = 45°. For angles of incidence greater than 45° in this medium, total internal reflection will occur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using sin θ_c = 1/n = 1/√2, we get θ_c = 45°. sin 30° = 0.5 (n = 2), sin 60° = √3/2 (n = 2/√3). The critical angle for n = √2 is exactly 45°.

questions.question_text: Optical fibres work on the principle of:
questions.explanation_correct: Optical fibres transmit light signals over long distances using total internal reflection. The core of the fibre has a higher refractive index than the cladding, so light entering at a suitable angle undergoes repeated TIR and propagates through the fibre with minimal loss.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While refraction occurs at the fibre entrance, the actual guiding mechanism inside the fibre is total internal reflection. The core (high n) surrounded by cladding (lower n) creates the conditions for TIR at every bounce.

questions.question_text: The critical angle for glass (n = 1.5) with respect to air is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: sin θ_c = n_air/n_glass = 1/1.5 = 2/3 ≈ 0.667. θ_c = sin⁻¹(0.667) ≈ 41.8°. Any ray in glass striking the glass-air interface at an angle greater than 41.8° will undergo total internal reflection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: sin θ_c = 1/1.5 = 0.667, giving θ_c ≈ 41.8°. 48.6° would be the critical angle for n ≈ 1.33 (water). 30° corresponds to n = 2, and 60° to n = 2/√3 ≈ 1.15.

questions.question_text: Diamonds sparkle brilliantly because:

options.text: diamond has a very low refractive index
diamond has a high refractive index (n ≈ 2.42), giving a small critical angle and extensive TIR
diamond absorbs all colours except white
diamond is transparent to all wavelengths

questions.explanation_correct: Diamond has a very high refractive index (n ≈ 2.42), which gives a very small critical angle: θ_c = sin⁻¹(1/2.42) ≈ 24.4°. This means most light entering the diamond undergoes total internal reflection multiple times before emerging, creating brilliant sparkle. The high dispersion also contributes to the 'fire' (rainbow colours).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A low refractive index would give a large critical angle and less TIR. The brilliant sparkle is due to the HIGH refractive index (n ≈ 2.42), which creates a small critical angle (≈ 24.4°), causing extensive total internal reflection inside the diamond.

questions.question_text: Which phenomenon causes mirages in deserts?

options.text: Total internal reflection of light in air layers of varying refractive index

questions.explanation_correct: Mirages occur due to total internal reflection in the atmosphere. Hot air near the ground has a lower refractive index than the cooler air above. Light from distant objects gradually bends as it passes through layers of decreasing refractive index, eventually undergoing TIR, creating an illusion of water on the road or desert floor.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mirages are not caused by diffraction, interference, or dispersion. They result from the continuous refraction and eventual TIR of light rays through air layers of gradually varying temperature (and hence refractive index).

questions.question_text: If the refractive index of a medium increases, the critical angle:
questions.explanation_correct: sin θ_c = 1/n (for the medium-air interface). As n increases, sin θ_c decreases, so θ_c decreases. A higher refractive index means a smaller critical angle, leading to more total internal reflection. This is why diamond (n = 2.42, θ_c ≈ 24.4°) sparkles more than glass (n = 1.5, θ_c ≈ 41.8°).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since sin θ_c = 1/n, increasing n decreases sin θ_c and hence θ_c. A higher refractive index gives a smaller critical angle, making TIR easier to achieve.

questions.question_text: A light ray enters a glass slab of refractive index √3 from air. For total internal reflection to occur at the glass-air interface on the other side, the angle of incidence at the first surface should be at least:

options.text: Total internal reflection cannot occur here

questions.explanation_correct: Critical angle at glass-air: sin θ_c = 1/√3, so θ_c = 30°. For TIR at the bottom surface, the angle of refraction inside the glass must be at least 90° − 30° = 60° (since the ray hits the parallel surface). Wait — for a parallel slab, if the ray enters at angle i in air, the refracted angle r in glass satisfies sin i = √3 sin r. For TIR at the bottom, r must equal θ_c = 30°. Then sin i = √3 × sin 30° = √3 × 0.5 = √3/2, giving i = 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The critical angle is θ_c = sin⁻¹(1/√3) = 30°. For the refracted ray inside the glass to hit the opposite surface at angle ≥ 30° (to undergo TIR), the incident angle must be: sin i = √3 sin 30° = √3/2, so i = 60°.

questions.question_text: An optical fibre has a core of refractive index 1.5 and cladding of refractive index 1.2. The critical angle at the core-cladding interface is:
questions.explanation_correct: sin θ_c = n_cladding/n_core = 1.2/1.5 = 0.8. Therefore θ_c = sin⁻¹(0.8) ≈ 53.1°. Light in the core hitting the core-cladding interface at angles greater than 53.1° will undergo TIR and remain in the core.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The critical angle is found from sin θ_c = n₂/n₁ = 1.2/1.5 = 0.8, giving θ_c = sin⁻¹(0.8). Using n₁/n₂ = 1.25 > 1, which cannot be a valid sine value. The ratio must be smaller n / larger n.

questions.question_text: When white light passes through a glass prism, it splits into its component colours. This phenomenon is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Dispersion is the splitting of white light into its component colours (spectrum) by a prism. It occurs because the refractive index of the glass varies with wavelength — violet light (shorter wavelength) has a higher refractive index and is deviated more than red light (longer wavelength).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diffraction is bending around obstacles, interference is superposition of waves, and polarisation restricts vibration direction. Dispersion specifically refers to the separation of light into its constituent wavelengths due to wavelength-dependent refraction.

questions.question_text: In the visible spectrum produced by a prism, which colour is deviated the most?
questions.explanation_correct: Violet light is deviated the most by a prism because it has the shortest wavelength among visible colours and the highest refractive index in glass (n_violet > n_red). Red is deviated the least. The order from most to least deviation is: VIBGYOR (violet, indigo, blue, green, yellow, orange, red).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Deviation depends on the refractive index, which increases with decreasing wavelength. Violet has the shortest wavelength and highest n, so it is deviated the most. Red, with the longest wavelength, is deviated the least.

questions.question_text: The refractive index of a prism at minimum deviation is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: At minimum deviation, the refractive index of the prism material is n = sin((A + δ_m)/2)/sin(A/2), where A is the prism angle and δ_m is the minimum angle of deviation. At minimum deviation, the ray passes symmetrically through the prism (angle of incidence = angle of emergence).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct formula is n = sin((A + δ_m)/2)/sin(A/2). Option C has the numerator and denominator swapped. The formula applies specifically at the minimum deviation condition.

questions.question_text: A prism has an angle of 60° and minimum deviation of 30°. The refractive index of the prism material is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: n = sin(45°)/sin(30°) = (√2/2)/(1/2) = √2 ≈ 1.414. The value 1.5 would require a different combination of A and δ_m. √3 ≈ 1.732 is too high for this case.

questions.question_text: At minimum deviation through a prism:

options.text: the angle of incidence is zero
the angle of incidence equals the angle of emergence
the refracted ray is parallel to the base of the prism

questions.explanation_correct: At minimum deviation: (1) the angle of incidence equals the angle of emergence (i = e), (2) the refracted ray inside the prism is parallel to the base, and (3) the ray passes symmetrically through the prism. Both conditions B and C are correct.
questions.explanation_incorrect: At minimum deviation, the ray path is symmetric: i = e, and the internal ray is parallel to the base. The angle of incidence is not zero — it has a specific value determined by the prism angle and refractive index.

questions.question_text: The angular dispersion produced by a thin prism of angle A is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a thin prism, deviation δ = (n − 1)A. Angular dispersion = δ_v − δ_r = (n_v − 1)A − (n_r − 1)A = (n_v − n_r)A. This is the angular separation between the violet and red rays after passing through the prism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angular dispersion = δ_v − δ_r = (n_v − n_r) × A for a thin prism. This uses the small angle formula δ = (n − 1)A. The dispersive power is defined as ω = (n_v − n_r)/(n_y − 1).

questions.question_text: A rainbow is formed due to:

options.text: only refraction of sunlight by water droplets
only reflection of sunlight by water droplets
refraction, total internal reflection, and dispersion in water droplets
diffraction of sunlight by water droplets

questions.explanation_correct: A rainbow is formed by the combination of refraction (as light enters and exits the droplet), internal reflection (inside the droplet), and dispersion (separation of colours due to wavelength-dependent refraction). The primary rainbow involves one internal reflection, and the secondary rainbow involves two.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A rainbow requires all three phenomena: refraction at the air-water interface, internal reflection inside the droplet, and dispersion (splitting of white light into colours). Diffraction is not the primary mechanism.

questions.question_text: For a thin prism of angle 5° and refractive index 1.5, the angle of deviation is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a thin prism, δ = (n − 1) × A = (1.5 − 1) × 5° = 0.5 × 5° = 2.5°. The thin prism formula is valid when the prism angle A is small (typically less than 10°).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the thin prism formula: δ = (n − 1)A = 0.5 × 5° = 2.5°. This formula simplifies the general prism equation for small angles.

questions.question_text: The lens maker's equation is:
questions.explanation_correct: The lens maker's equation is 1/f = (n − 1)(1/R₁ − 1/R₂), where n is the refractive index of the lens material (relative to the surrounding medium), and R₁, R₂ are the radii of curvature of the two surfaces with appropriate sign convention.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct form uses subtraction (1/R₁ − 1/R₂), not addition. The factor is (n − 1), not n. And the formula gives 1/f, not f directly.

questions.question_text: The power of a lens is defined as:
questions.explanation_correct: The power of a lens is P = 1/f, where f is the focal length in metres. The SI unit of power is the dioptre (D). A convex lens has positive power, and a concave lens has negative power. 1 D = 1 m⁻¹.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Power P = 1/f, with f in metres and P in dioptres (D). Using f in cm would give power in cm⁻¹, which is not the standard unit. Power is inversely proportional to focal length, not directly proportional.

questions.question_text: The power of a combination of two thin lenses in contact is:
questions.explanation_correct: For two thin lenses in contact, the combined power is P = P₁ + P₂ (or equivalently, 1/f = 1/f₁ + 1/f₂). Powers add algebraically, so a convex lens (+P) and a concave lens (−P) can partially or fully cancel each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Powers of thin lenses in contact add: P = P₁ + P₂. This is because 1/f = 1/f₁ + 1/f₂ for lenses in contact. Products or differences of powers are not correct.

questions.question_text: A convex lens has focal length 25 cm. Its power is:
questions.explanation_correct: P = 1/f = 1/0.25 = +4 D. The focal length must be converted to metres: 25 cm = 0.25 m. A convex (converging) lens has a positive focal length and positive power.
questions.explanation_incorrect: f = 25 cm = 0.25 m. P = 1/f = 1/0.25 = +4 D. Using f in cm (P = 1/25 = 0.04) gives the wrong answer. The positive sign indicates a converging lens.

questions.question_text: Two lenses of power +3 D and −1 D are placed in contact. The focal length of the combination is:
questions.explanation_correct: Combined power P = P₁ + P₂ = +3 + (−1) = +2 D. Focal length f = 1/P = 1/2 = 0.5 m = 50 cm. The combination acts as a converging lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: P_total = 3 + (−1) = 2 D. f = 1/P = 1/2 m = 50 cm. The combination is converging (positive power) with a focal length of 50 cm.

questions.question_text: A biconvex lens has radii of curvature R₁ = 20 cm and R₂ = 30 cm, and is made of glass with n = 1.5. The focal length is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: For a biconvex lens: R₁ = +20, R₂ = −30. 1/f = 0.5 × (1/20 + 1/30) = 0.5 × 5/60 = 1/24. Therefore f = 24 cm.

questions.question_text: The thin lens formula is:
questions.explanation_correct: The thin lens formula is 1/v − 1/u = 1/f, where v is the image distance, u is the object distance, and f is the focal length. Note the subtraction sign, which distinguishes it from the mirror formula (which uses addition).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The lens formula uses subtraction: 1/v − 1/u = 1/f. The mirror formula uses addition: 1/v + 1/u = 1/f. Confusing these is a common error.

questions.question_text: A convex lens made of glass (n = 1.5) has focal length 20 cm in air. If it is immersed in water (n = 4/3), its focal length becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: In air: 1/f_air = (n_g − 1)(1/R₁ − 1/R₂) = 0.5 × K, where K = (1/R₁ − 1/R₂). In water: 1/f_water = (n_g/n_w − 1) × K = (1.5/(4/3) − 1) × K = (9/8 − 1) × K = (1/8) × K. Ratio: f_water/f_air = 0.5/(1/8) = 4. So f_water = 4 × 20 = 80 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In water, the relative refractive index changes from (n − 1) = 0.5 to (n_g/n_w − 1) = 0.125. The focal length increases by a factor of 0.5/0.125 = 4, giving f = 80 cm. The lens becomes much weaker in water.

questions.question_text: A convex lens of focal length 10 cm is combined with a concave lens of focal length 15 cm. The equivalent focal length of the combination is:
questions.explanation_correct: 1/f = 1/f₁ + 1/f₂ = 1/10 + 1/(−15) = 1/10 − 1/15 = (3 − 2)/30 = 1/30. So f = +30 cm. The positive sign indicates the combination is converging (convex effect dominates).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1/f = 1/10 − 1/15 = (3 − 2)/30 = 1/30. f = 30 cm (positive, converging). The convex lens is stronger than the concave lens, so the combination converges light.

questions.question_text: An equiconvex lens (both radii = R) made of glass of refractive index 1.5 has a focal length equal to:
questions.explanation_correct: For an equiconvex lens, R₁ = +R and R₂ = −R. 1/f = (n − 1)(1/R₁ − 1/R₂) = (1.5 − 1)(1/R − 1/(−R)) = 0.5 × 2/R = 1/R. Therefore f = R.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1/f = (n − 1)(1/R + 1/R) = 0.5 × 2/R = 1/R. So f = R for n = 1.5. For n = 2, f = R/2. The focal length equals the radius of curvature for an equiconvex lens of n = 1.5.

questions.question_text: The magnifying power of a simple microscope (magnifying glass) for the image at the near point is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a simple microscope, when the image is formed at the near point (D = 25 cm), the magnifying power M = 1 + D/f. When the image is at infinity (relaxed eye), M = D/f. The maximum magnification is achieved when the image is at the near point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: M = D/f is the magnification when the image is at infinity (relaxed viewing). For the image at the near point, M = 1 + D/f, which gives a slightly higher magnification.

questions.question_text: The magnifying power of an astronomical telescope in normal adjustment (image at infinity) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The magnifying power of an astronomical (refracting) telescope in normal adjustment is M = f_o/f_e, where f_o is the focal length of the objective and f_e is the focal length of the eyepiece. A large f_o and small f_e give high magnification. The tube length is f_o + f_e.
questions.explanation_incorrect: M = f_o/f_e for a telescope. The objective has a large focal length for high magnification, and the eyepiece has a short focal length. f_e/f_o would give a value less than 1, which is not useful for a telescope.

questions.question_text: In a compound microscope, the objective lens forms:
questions.explanation_correct: In a compound microscope, the objective lens has a short focal length and the object is placed just beyond its focus. It forms a real, magnified, inverted image on the other side. This image acts as the object for the eyepiece, which further magnifies it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The objective must form a real image (to serve as the object for the eyepiece) and it must be magnified (to achieve high total magnification). A virtual or diminished image from the objective would defeat the purpose of the microscope.

questions.question_text: A magnifying glass has a focal length of 5 cm. Its magnifying power when the image is at the near point (D = 25 cm) is:
questions.explanation_correct: M = 1 + D/f = 1 + 25/5 = 1 + 5 = 6. This is the maximum magnification possible with this magnifying glass, achieved when the image is at the near point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: M = 1 + D/f = 1 + 25/5 = 6. If the image were at infinity, M = D/f = 5. The extra '1' in the formula accounts for the additional magnification when the eye is accommodating.

questions.question_text: An astronomical telescope has an objective of focal length 150 cm and an eyepiece of focal length 5 cm. Its magnifying power in normal adjustment is:
questions.explanation_correct: M = f_o/f_e = 150/5 = 30. The telescope magnifies the angular size of distant objects by 30 times. The length of the telescope in normal adjustment is f_o + f_e = 150 + 5 = 155 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: M = f_o/f_e = 150/5 = 30. The value 155 is the tube length (f_o + f_e), not the magnification. 0.033 = f_e/f_o is the inverse.

questions.question_text: To increase the magnifying power of a telescope, one should:
questions.explanation_correct: Since M = f_o/f_e, to increase magnification we should increase f_o (larger objective focal length) and decrease f_e (smaller eyepiece focal length). This is why telescopes have long objective lenses and short eyepieces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: M = f_o/f_e. To maximise this ratio, increase the numerator (f_o) and decrease the denominator (f_e). Increasing both or decreasing both may not increase the ratio.

questions.question_text: The length of a compound microscope is 15 cm. The focal length of the objective is 1 cm and of the eyepiece is 5 cm. The magnifying power for the image at the near point is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: Tube length L = 15 cm, f_o = 1 cm, f_e = 5 cm. Image distance of objective ≈ L − f_e = 15 − 5 = 10 cm (approx). Wait — more precisely, the image distance of the objective v_o ≈ L (approximately, when object is near f_o). Magnification of objective m_o ≈ L/f_o is approximate. Better: M ≈ (L/(f_o))(D/f_e) for image at infinity, or (L/f_o)(1 + D/f_e) for near point. But L here is the separation between lenses minus focal lengths = 15 − 1 − 5 = 9 cm. M = (9/1)(1 + 25/5) = 9 × 6 = 54.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tube length between lenses is 15 cm. The image distance of objective ≈ v_o, and the separation of lenses L ≈ v_o + f_e. The mechanical tube length (image distance of objective − f_o) ≈ L − f_o − f_e = 9 cm. M = (9/1)(1 + 25/5) = 9 × 6 = 54.

questions.question_text: In a reflecting telescope, the objective is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a reflecting (Newtonian) telescope, the objective is a concave mirror (instead of a convex lens used in refracting telescopes). Reflecting telescopes avoid chromatic aberration and can be made with larger apertures. Newton designed the first practical reflecting telescope.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reflecting telescopes use a concave mirror as the objective. Refracting telescopes use a convex lens. A concave mirror gathers and focuses light without chromatic aberration, and large mirrors are easier to manufacture than large lenses.

questions.question_text: The resolving power of a telescope increases with:

options.text: increasing focal length of the objective
increasing focal length of the eyepiece

questions.explanation_correct: The resolving power of a telescope is proportional to the diameter (aperture) of its objective: R.P. = D/(1.22λ). A larger aperture collects more light and reduces the diffraction limit, allowing the telescope to distinguish finer details and separate closely spaced objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Resolving power depends on the aperture D of the objective, not on focal lengths. A larger objective aperture reduces the minimum resolvable angle (θ_min = 1.22λ/D), improving resolution.

questions.question_text: A convex mirror always forms an image that is:
questions.explanation_correct: A convex mirror always forms a virtual, erect, and diminished image regardless of the object position. The image is formed behind the mirror between the pole and the focus. This property makes convex mirrors useful as rear-view mirrors in vehicles (wider field of view).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unlike concave mirrors which can form real or virtual images depending on object position, a convex mirror always forms a virtual, erect, and diminished image. This gives a wider field of view.

questions.question_text: A person uses spectacles of power −2 D. The focal length of the lens and the nature of the defect are:
questions.explanation_correct: P = −2 D, so f = 1/P = 1/(−2) = −0.5 m = −50 cm. A negative power indicates a concave (diverging) lens, which is used to correct myopia (short-sightedness). In myopia, the image forms before the retina, and a concave lens diverges the light to push the image back onto the retina.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Negative power → concave lens → corrects myopia. Positive power → convex lens → corrects hypermetropia. f = 1/P = −0.5 m = −50 cm.

questions.question_text: The objective of a compound microscope should have:

options.text: large focal length and large aperture
small focal length and small aperture
small focal length and large aperture
large focal length and small aperture

questions.explanation_correct: The objective of a compound microscope should have a small focal length (for high magnification, since m_o ≈ L/f_o) and a small aperture (to reduce spherical aberration and increase depth of field). The eyepiece should also have a small focal length for high angular magnification.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A small focal length gives high magnification (m_o ∝ 1/f_o). A small aperture helps with aberration correction in microscopes. For telescopes, a large aperture is needed (for resolving power), but for microscopes, a small, precision-ground objective is preferred.

questions.question_text: The dispersive power of a material is defined as:
questions.explanation_correct: Dispersive power ω = (n_v − n_r)/(n_y − 1), where n_v, n_r, n_y are the refractive indices for violet, red, and yellow (mean) light respectively. The numerator represents angular dispersion for a thin prism, and the denominator represents the mean deviation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dispersive power = angular dispersion / mean deviation = (n_v − n_r)/(n_y − 1). It is a property of the material, not the prism angle. Higher dispersive power means greater colour separation.
